# Summer Camp and Seasonal Childcare Options

## Summer Childcare Challenges
School-year care doesn't cover summer break:
- 10-12 weeks of summer
- Higher daily rates
- Different licensing rules
- Limited availability

## Types of Summer Programs

### Summer Day Camps
- Full-day programs
- Activity-based (sports, arts, STEM)
- Public parks and recreation
- Private camps

### Extended Learning Programs
- School-based summer programs
- Academic enrichment
- May be free or subsidized

### Childcare Center Summer Programs
- Year-round centers continue
- Some expand for summer
- Same providers, longer hours

## Subsidy Coverage

### CalWORKs
- Covers summer care if need continues
- Same provider or different allowed

### Alternative Payment
- Summer care covered
- May need to find summer provider
- Day camps may qualify

## Planning Tips
- Start planning in March
- Register early for popular camps
- Check subsidy rules for day camps
- Combine programs if needed

## Free/Low-Cost Options
- Parks and recreation departments
- Library programs
- Community organizations
- Church vacation Bible school programs

# Childcare During School Breaks

## Types of Breaks

### Winter Break
- 2-3 weeks typically
- December-January
- Holiday closures compound challenge

### Spring Break
- 1-2 weeks
- March-April
- Many providers remain open

### Teacher Work Days
- Scattered throughout year
- School closed, childcare needed
- Often minimal notice

## Coverage Options

### Extended Day Programs
- Some offer break coverage
- Check school-based programs

### Year-Round Childcare
- Centers typically open
- Family childcare often available
- May have adjusted schedules

### Drop-In Care
- Emergency option
- Check ahead for availability
- Higher daily rates

### Family and Friends
- Grandparents
- Relatives
- Friends swap care
- TrustLine registration recommended

## Subsidy Considerations
- Need still must be documented
- Provider may change for breaks
- Communicate with AP agency

## Planning Ahead
- Get school calendar at year start
- Plan for each break
- Have backup arrangements
- Budget for additional costs

# Part-Time and Part-Week Childcare

## Who Needs Part-Time Care
- Part-time workers
- Work-from-home parents
- Students in school
- Parents with flexible schedules
- Shared custody situations

## Types of Part-Time Arrangements

### Half-Day Programs
- Morning or afternoon
- Preschool most common
- Lower cost than full-day

### Part-Week Care
- 2-3 days per week
- MWF or T/Th schedules
- Some providers accommodate

### Drop-In Care
- As-needed basis
- Limited availability
- Higher hourly rates

## Availability Challenges
- Most subsidies designed for full-time work
- Providers prefer full-time enrollment
- May be harder to find part-time slots

## Subsidy Coverage

### Part-Time Employment
- Subsidies based on actual hours
- Minimum hours may apply
- Document work schedule

### Variable Schedules
- Can be accommodated
- May need frequent updates
- Keep agency informed

## Tips for Finding Part-Time Care
- Family childcare more flexible
- Nanny shares work well
- Consider co-op preschools
- Ask about partial enrollment

# Sibling Care and Family Discounts

## Placing Siblings Together

### Benefits
- Simpler logistics
- Emotional support for children
- May get discounts
- One relationship to maintain

### Challenges
- Different age needs
- Not all programs serve all ages
- May need separate programs

## Family Discounts

### Common Discount Structures
- 10-15% off second child
- Third child deeper discount
- Family rate caps

### Ask About
- Multi-child discounts
- Family rate policies
- Registration fee waivers

## Subsidy Considerations

### Same Provider for Siblings
- Often preferred by families
- Subsidies can cover both
- Separate paperwork may be needed

### Different Programs
- Infant may need specialized care
- Preschooler in school program
- School-age in after school
- All can be subsidized

## Tips for Multiple Children
- Apply for all children at once
- Ask about sibling priority
- Consider family childcare for mixed ages
- Coordinate schedules

## Large Family Considerations
- May exceed provider capacity
- Multiple providers may be needed
- Prioritize youngest for licensed care
- Older children may qualify for after-school programs

# Transportation and Childcare Logistics

## Common Transportation Challenges
- Getting children to/from care
- Coordinating with work schedule
- Multiple children at different locations
- Public transit limitations

## Provider Transportation Options

### Some Centers Offer
- Before/after school pickup
- Field trip transportation
- (Always verify licensing for transport)

### School Bus Coordination
- Some programs at bus stops
- Before/after school care at school sites

## Self-Transport Considerations

### Choose Care Near
- Home (easier before work)
- Work (easier for emergencies)
- School (seamless transitions)

### Multiple Stops
- Plan efficient routes
- Build in extra time
- Have backup plans

## Subsidy and Transportation

### Not Typically Covered
- Transportation costs generally not subsidized
- Your responsibility to arrange

### Mileage Documentation
- May be tax deductible
- Keep records for tax purposes

## Alternative Solutions
- Carpool with other parents
- Family member help
- Public transit where feasible
- Choose provider based on location

## Safety Requirements
- Licensed transport must meet regulations
- Car seats provided or bring own
- Check provider's transport record

# Childcare for Children in Foster Care

## Automatic Eligibility
Children in foster care have automatic priority for:
- CalWORKs childcare
- Alternative Payment Program
- Head Start
- State Preschool

## Who Qualifies
- Children in foster homes
- Children in relative/kinship care
- Children with foster family agencies

## Special Provisions

### Resource Families
- Foster families can use subsidized care
- No income limit typically
- Priority placement

### Respite Care
- Temporary relief for foster parents
- May be covered separately
- Check with county

## Application Process

1. Contact county child welfare
2. Request childcare authorization
3. Choose provider
4. Provider receives payment directly

## Documentation
- Foster care placement letter
- Case worker verification
- Less documentation required generally

## Support Services
- Trauma-informed care preferences
- Therapeutic childcare options
- Coordination with case plans
- Stability considerations

## Resources
- County child welfare office
- Foster family agencies
- Resource family support programs
- Post-adoption childcare may also qualify

# Resource and Referral (R&R) Agency Services

## What R&R Agencies Do

### For Families
- Childcare referrals (free)
- Subsidy information
- Application assistance
- Community resources

### For Providers
- Training and professional development
- Business support
- Licensing assistance
- Quality improvement

## How to Use R&R Services

### Getting Referrals
1. Call local R&R agency
2. Describe your needs:
   - Child ages
   - Care hours needed
   - Location preference
   - Special needs
3. Receive list of providers
4. Contact and visit providers

### Referral Information Includes
- Licensed providers in your area
- Type of care offered
- Ages served
- Hours of operation
- Contact information

## What R&R Can't Do
- Recommend specific providers
- Guarantee quality
- Make placements
- Provide care directly

## Find Your R&R
- **CRRN Network**: California Resource and Referral Network
- **By county**: Each county has designated R&R
- **211**: United Way can connect you

## Beyond Referrals
- Consumer education workshops
- Choosing quality care guidance
- Understanding subsidies
- Special needs resources

# Childcare for Student Parents

## On-Campus Childcare

### Community Colleges
- Most California community colleges have child development centers
- Priority for student parents
- Low-cost or free (subsidies available)
- Convenient to classes

### Universities
- UC and CSU systems have campus childcare
- Long wait lists common
- Apply early

## CalWORKs for Students

### Welfare-to-Work
- Education counts as approved activity
- Childcare covered during school
- Study time may be covered
- Transportation between school and childcare

## CCAMPIS Grants
Child Care Access Means Parents in School program:
- Federal program for student parents
- Campus-based childcare support
- Income eligible
- Check with financial aid

## Other Options

### Alternative Payment
- Student status counts as activity
- Income eligible families
- Off-campus providers included

### Head Start
- If income eligible
- Good for preschool-age
- Comprehensive services

## Student Parent Challenges
- Varying class schedules
- Evening classes
- Study time childcare
- Summer and break schedules

## Tips for Student Parents
- Apply to campus childcare immediately upon enrollment
- Explore all subsidy options
- Connect with student parent programs
- Utilize campus resources

# Self-Employment and Childcare Subsidies

## Qualifying as Self-Employed

### Documentation Needed
- Business license or registration
- Tax returns showing business income
- Profit and loss statements
- Client contracts or invoices
- Business bank statements

## Income Calculation

### Gross vs Net
- Self-employment income is gross minus business expenses
- Keep good records
- May need Schedule C or similar

### Variable Income
- May average over several months
- New businesses may estimate
- Update if income changes significantly

## Activity Requirement

### Work Hours
- Need to document work hours
- Self-reported but must be reasonable
- May need business records

### Home-Based Business
- Working from home counts
- Need for childcare still valid
- Can't watch children while working

## Special Situations

### Gig Workers
- Uber, Lyft, DoorDash, etc.
- Document earnings
- Variable schedule documentation

### Freelancers
- Contract work
- Client documentation
- Invoice records

### Small Business Owners
- Business registration
- Financial records
- May have employees

## Tips for Self-Employed
- Keep detailed records
- Separate business and personal finances
- Update agency on income changes
- Be prepared to verify work

# Multiple Language Resources for Families

## Language Access Rights

California law requires:
- Services in threshold languages
- Translation of vital documents
- Interpreter services available

## Common Languages Supported

### Widespread Support
- English
- Spanish
- Chinese (Mandarin, Cantonese)
- Vietnamese
- Korean
- Tagalog

### Regional Languages
- Russian (some areas)
- Armenian (LA, Glendale)
- Hmong (Central Valley)
- Punjabi (Central Valley)
- Arabic (various)

## Getting Help in Your Language

### R&R Agencies
- Bilingual staff often available
- Translation services
- Materials in multiple languages

### County Offices
- Must provide language access
- Ask for interpreter
- Written materials available

## Bilingual Childcare

### Finding Bilingual Providers
- Ask R&R about language capabilities
- Many family childcare providers bilingual
- Language immersion programs

### Benefits for Children
- Native language development
- Cultural connection
- Bilingual skill building

## Online Resources
- MyChildCarePlan has language options
- CDSS materials translated
- Head Start serves many languages

## If You Need Interpretation
- Request in advance if possible
- Agencies must provide
- Phone interpretation available
